"In May 2020, during the nationwide lockdown due to the COVID-19 pandemic, Sood helped thousands of stranded Indian migrant workers to reach their homes throughout India by arranging buses, special trains and chartered flights for them. His charity social service during the pandemic was lauded and was hailed as a real life hero in India. On July 25th 2020, during Covid19 pandemic time, a video of the farmer's daughters ploughing the field by working like bulls with yoke on their shoulders went viral over social media, Sonu Sood sent the family with a tractor by evening."

Today we have reached a landmark figure of helping sixteen thousand families with food and relief material that will last them for two weeks. Besides Mumbai and Greater Mumbai, we have reached to Sangli, Gadchiroli, Kurkheda, Bhamragarh, Aheri and other villages in Vidarbha. We procured 20 thousand litres of milk from farmers in Solapur to ease their stress and later distributed to the needy. In Antop Hill, Wadala, Kurla, Sewri, Dharavi, Mumbra, Mira Road, we have reached out to five thousand families in three days. Through our relief work, we also came across migrants who have been walking barefoot all the way from Mumbai to Uttar Pradesh, walking 15000 thousand kilometres on feet. We have made sure to extend help to them along with ten lac migrants in the city who are anxious about their future. In terms of numbers, in the last three weeks, we have distributed eighty thousand kilo rice, fifty thousand kilo dal, hundred thousand kilo flour, and fifty thousand litres of sunflower oil among other essentials.

Her initiative began in late March when a friend called her in the wee hours to inform her about 1800 migrant workers who were stuck in the city and had not eaten for the whole day.she revealed that she and her friend decided to act immediately. The Mahasrashtra government helped them in their initiave and Chauhan has been feeding these migrant workers and other people in need on the streets of the city every day.
